'Caspases', or cysteine-aspartic proteases or 'c'ysteine-dependent 'asp'artate-
directed prote'ases' are a family of cysteine proteases that play essential
roles in apoptosis (programmed cell death), necrosis, and inflammation.

Caspases are essential in cells for apoptosis, or programmed cell death, in
development and most other stages of adult life, and have been termed
"executioner" proteins for their roles in the cell. Some caspases are also
required in the immune system for the maturation of lymphocytes. Failure of
apoptosis is one of the main contributions to tumour development and autoimmune
diseases; this, coupled with the unwanted apoptosis that occurs with ischemia or
Alzheimer's disease, has stimulated interest in caspases as potential
therapeutic targets since they were discovered in the mid-1990s.
